oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: The Wagoneers Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with the Wagoneers (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Wagoneers; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Monte Warden radio spot introducing the Wagoneers, Biff Collie, and the Music City Album Review -- (00:09) Warden radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (00:17) Warden radio spot for the commercial break -- (00:27) Warden radio spot introducing 'the Biffer' and the Music City Album Review -- (00:38) Warden radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (00:47) Warden radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (01:02) Collie asks Warden to change position, and Warden describes "Sit a Little Closer" as a song he had to push his publishing company into adding to the album -- (02:35) Warden recalls how he met Thomas A. Lewis, and how he and Lewis decided to create the Wagoneers -- (03:27) Warden recalls the Wagoneers' first performance to be in a bar called Steamboat Springs -- (04:22) Collie inquires about where Warden was born -- (04:34) Warden recalls how his family had no musical talents, and Warden describes a time where Collie booked Elvis Presley -- (05:57) "Everybody Calls My Baby Honey" is told by Warden to be a track he did not enjoy -- (06:42) Collie has Warden reflect on his childhood aspirations, and both discuss Warden's desire to fly -- (07:27) Warden discusses how he wrote "Por Favor Se�or" while in San Antonio -- (08:24) Collie inquires about Austin's musical influence on Warden -- (09:57) Collie and Warden discuss "Take Me," and Warden reveals it was the Wagoneers' first waltz -- (10:49) Warden describes the difference between playing for a Texas crowd against any other state -- (12:55) Warden says that "Champagne And Chandeliers" had been originally written in a different key -- (14:09) Warden discusses how the Wagoneers were presented in the video for "I Wanna Know Her Again" -- (17:53) The title tune "Good Fortune" is discussed to be Warden's expression of his success to that point -- (18:36) "She Wouldn't Have It" is told by Warden to be written about Maria McKee -- (19:31) Warden says that, if he spends too much time on a tune, he will give up on it -- (20:11) "Atlanta" is described by Warden to be about a Civil War veteran Billy Sherman -- (21:03) Collie and Warden discuss how Warden desires to give his albums historical significance -- (22:24) "Test Of Time" producer Paul Kennerley is reflected on for his consideration -- (24:31) Warden reveals that he wrote or co-wrote every track on the album -- (25:02) Warden reflects on what motivates his song-writing -- (25:42) Warden reveals the Wagoneers end each show with "I Can't Stay," and Warden reflects on getting Kayton Roberts to perform on the album -- (27:20) Warden thanks Collie -- (27:41) Warden describes why the Wagoneers dedicated their album to Tom Landry
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Wagoneers (Musical group); Collie, Biff;
